Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Mechanical and Oral Antibiotic Bowel Preparation Versus No Bowel Preparation for Elective Colectomy

Background: This study aimed to evaluate the effect of mechanical and oral antibiotic bowel preparation (MOABP) compared to no bowel preparation (NBP) on surgical-site infections (SSIs) in patients undergoing elective colectomy.

Methods: This was a subgroup analysis of the MOBILE trial, a multicentre, single-blinded, randomised controlled trial conducted in four Finnish hospitals. Patients scheduled for elective colonic resection were randomised to either MOABP or NBP. The primary outcome was the rate of SSI within 30 days post-surgery. Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed. Blinding was applied to recruiters, treating physicians, surgeons, data collectors, and analysts.

Results: A total of 381 patients were randomised: 217 to right colectomy (106 MOABP, 111 NBP) and 164 to left colectomy (84 MOABP, 80 NBP). In right colectomy, SSI rates were 7% (MOABP) and 9% (NBP) (OR 0.71, 95% CI 0.26 to 1.95; P = 0.510). In left colectomy, SSI rates were 6% (MOABP) and 10% (NBP) (OR 0.57, 95% CI 0.18 to 1.82; P = 0.338). No significant differences in overall morbidity or adverse events were observed.

Interpretation: MOABP did not significantly reduce SSI rates or complications compared to NBP in either right or left colectomy. Further research is needed to confirm these findings.

Trial registration: NCT02652637

Funding: Vatsatautien Tutkimussäätiö Foundation, Mary and Georg Ehrnrooth’s Foundation, Finnish Cancer Foundation, Helsinki University Research Funds.
